newsitem.title: USA: Shell Oil sees 97 capex $3.8 bln.
newsitem.headline: Shell Oil sees 97 capex $3.8 bln.

text.p: Shell Oil Co, the U.S. subsidiary of the Anglo-Dutch Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said Friday that it plans to spend $3.8 billion on capital and exploratory expenditures in 1997, an increase of $100 million from budgeted 1996 levels.
About $2.5 billion will be spent on exploration and production, with $800 million earmarked for the Oil Products division and $500 million for the Chemicals division, the company said in a statement.

"Our 1997 capital and exploratory spending program remains near the 1996 level and continues to support profitable growth opportunities in all three business sectors," said Philip Carroll, president and chief executive of Shell Oil.

The spending "supports our continuing efforts to accelerate production from our Gulf of Mexico discoveries. Based upon encouraging results from our existing operations, existing and planned developments and expected new opportunities, our anticipated average annual production growth rate through 2001 is about 15 pct for both oil and gas."
The Oil Products spending is mainly for upgraded and new service stations, offset by reduced refining expenditures as the modernization of Shell's Martinez, California refinery are completed.
